text:
I don’t think I’ve ever checked anything weekly. Monthly, we’ve always focused on what drives $$ and work backwards. So:
• Sales
• MQLs
• Leads
• Traffic
• Keywords

text:
I report traffic and conversions on a weekly basis for one of my customers. Rest are monthly.

We have automated reports running these so it's lift and shift for me to share with the wider team.

text: Tuesday deep thoughts re content marketing about content marketing -- My small agency provides writing services for fin svcs, tech + healthcare companies. We send an email newsletter to clients / prospects / friends every 6 weeks or so. Since we started it about 3-4 years ago, the newsletters have focused on writing tips -- simple, straightforward pieces that underscore our expertise in this area. We've gotten a decent open rate and some good responses. The problem: We've basically exhausted that genre, so we're trying to figure out what else our audience would want to hear from us. They're largely in marketing roles at corporations, or on the creative side at agencies. Any thoughts?

elements.text: Tuesday deep thoughts re content marketing about content marketing -- My small agency provides writing services for fin svcs, tech + healthcare companies. We send an email newsletter to clients / prospects / friends every 6 weeks or so. Since we started it about 3-4 years ago, the newsletters have focused on writing tips -- simple, straightforward pieces that underscore our expertise in this area. We've gotten a decent open rate and some good responses. The problem: We've basically exhausted that genre, so we're trying to figure out what else our audience would want to hear from us. They're largely in marketing roles at corporations, or on the creative side at agencies. Any thoughts?

text:
Assuming you can get at least a few dozen responses, I'd send an open-ended survey to your email list.

It can be as simple as one or two questions (e.g., "What's your biggest marketing challenge right now?")

Even if the themes you get from their responses are broad, you should be able to identify some specific topic ideas that riff off those themes.

As a species, we're pretty terrible at telling people what we want (especially when getting it requires opening our wallet—just ask any SaaS marketer who's asked customers about features), so I wouldn't ask questions like, "What should we write about?"

As a species, we're pretty terrible at telling people what we want (especially when getting it requires opening our wallet—just ask any SaaS marketer who's asked customers about features), so I wouldn't ask questions like, "What should we write about?"

text:
Is your business transactional or does it need to build a relationship with the customer? 

This is an important distinction for measuring SEO (or any channel). If your business is purely transactional, you’ll want know how efficiently your traffic converts into customers. If you need to build a relationship with your audience, it’s still important to know how efficiently your traffic converts. But you also need to understand how traffic translates into engagement, loyalty, and growth. 

Some metrics to consider:

Return visitor rate (RVR)
• Sessions per user
• Session frequency and recency 
• Page depth per user
• Compound monthly growth rate (CMGR)
You should be able to track these metrics with any web analytics tool. More advanced metrics like “engaged time” and “engaged sessions” require tools that enable you to create calculated metrics.

text:
Sounds like a great client! 

So yeah, the engagement and loyalty metrics I mentioned will demonstrate that your content is engaging. Combined with compound growth, you’ll show the effect engagement and loyalty have on retaining an audience (and reducing the cost of acquisition). Juxtaposed with conversation, you’ll prove the ROI of a content strategy that attracts and retains a highly engaged audience.

text: It's an important tool in my toolkit. But it's not my focus. I currently run content marketing for Udemy, previously oversaw global content marketing for Eventbrite, and helped a few startups lay the foundation for their content marketing operations. My career is built on designing operational efficient content strategies, which is rooted in an obsession with measurement and optimization.
